Adolescence.content:
“Within five years, I lost both my aunt and my mother to cancer. So, when I go to H Mart, I’m not just on the hunt for cuttlefish and three bunches of scallions for a buck; I’m searching for memories. I’m collecting the evidence that the Korean half of my identity didn’t die when they did. H Mart is the bridge that guides me away from the memories that haunt me, of chemo head and skeletal bodies and logging milligrams of hydrocodone.”

— Crying in H Mart: A Memoir by Michelle Zauner
https://a.co/1QSvs1R
Adolescence.title: Crying in H Mart: A Memoir

Adolescence.content:
「You launch into a monologue about how we’ve been socialized. Where did we learn about the American dream? What role models were available to us? You pontificate on the meaning of Michael Chang. Do the lessons passed down to us by books or movies or TV apply to our lives as Asian kids with Asian parents, or do they make us feel inadequate? Why are we always working so hard, proving our smarts, living up to someone else’s standards? Maybe it’s all a trap. Why are we looking out for help, when it’s all around us? We are not men without a culture. We just have to make it ourselves.」

—Stay True: A Memoir (Pulitzer Prize Winner)，作者：Hua Hsu
https://a.co/2BF5xuh
Adolescence.concept: Asian American experience, cultural pride, identity
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content:
「He models his behavior after characters on TV, and he has no idea who he really is. In the margins, Ken sketched out a statement of philosophy, riffs and observations around Asian American identity.」

—Stay True: A Memoir (Pulitzer Prize Winner)，作者：Hua Hsu
https://a.co/6WTaX9x
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content:
「The immigrant’s resourcefulness requires an exhaustion of possibilities. You may master tenses and forms, grammatical rules, what passes for style. And yet, consequently, you may struggle to hold a conversation with your grandparents.」

—Stay True: A Memoir (Pulitzer Prize Winner)，作者：Hua Hsu
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content:
「My father often referred to himself as “Eastern” or “Oriental.” He didn’t get why it was so important to call ourselves “Asian American,” a term that barely existed when he first arrived in the United States.」

—Stay True: A Memoir (Pulitzer Prize Winner)，作者：Hua Hsu
https://a.co/j2H9z4H
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content:
「My parents were spending more time in Taiwan. I had prepaid phone card numbers written everywhere, but I could never remember which ones worked, or which country and city codes to dial.」

—Stay True: A Memoir (Pulitzer Prize Winner)，作者：Hua Hsu
https://a.co/4IjXHKv
Adolescence.concept: Hua Hsu, Pulitzer Prize Winner, SIM3, adolescence, assimilation, attachment, belonging, cultural, cultural difference, cultural pride, culture, embarrassment, family, fear, identity, identity crisis, immigrant experience, immigrants, inhibitions, isolation, language, language barrier, memoir, minority experience, personal preference, problem, rejection, second generation immigrant, second-generation immigrant
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: I would definitely like to improve my Mandarin, though I'm uncertain about its practical application. Potentially, it could enhance my communication with my parents. Nevertheless, there are moments when I feel a stronger need to speak English, even with my Italian friend. This preference may be influenced by my surroundings or circumstances. Interestingly, my cousins, who moved here in their early 20s, have experienced significant assimilation pressure. However, their struggle lies with assimilating not just into white society, but also among Asian Americans.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: My brother despised Weekend Chinese school, so I never attended. My mom didn't want the hassle of another child complaining. Despite his dislike for it, he did feel more assimilated to the culture as he improved his Mandarin, which is now better than mine. Additionally, he can understand Taiwanese.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: In elementary school, my cousins from Taiwan visited. They didn't speak English and stayed with me during summer school. I was embarrassed having to speak Mandarin in public so they could understand. Now, I'm grateful for being bilingual and am not embarrassed to speak Mandarin anymore.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Growing up, my mom and I listened to a lot of music. It's incredibly nostalgic for me, reminding me of my mom and my brother. I've attended a Leehom Wang concert, but never a Mayday. I remember in middle school, I went to a concert in Vegas. I was on a tour bus with a bunch of Taiwanese people. It was so different that I was too embarrassed to tell my friends where I went that weekend.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Growing up, I felt unattractive, believing that if I wasn't white, I wasn't beautiful. Seeing attractive Asian representations in media was a very exciting time. These recent cultural moments definitely contribute. Now, everyone's really into KPop, too.
Adolescence.concept: Asian American experience, cultural pride, racial representation
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: We play this Taiwanese game called Red 10. These moments truly contribute to my happiness of being Taiwanese. It can be hard to connect with my dad, but he's improving his emotional intelligence. Many Asian families can relate to a parent commenting on their appearance. Having a game like this was a buffer for us, showing our love for each other in a non-verbal way. My parents don't tell me they love me or that they're proud of me. They're not used to that kind of language. We don't really hug or kiss. Playing games was a moment where we all came together, spending quality time. Movies like Crazy Rich Asians, despite not being a cultural movement, were significant.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: I haven't asked my mom if it hurt her when we asked her not to prepare Asian food for lunch. Honestly, making a peanut butter jelly sandwich is easier than preparing something overnight. She was busy, so it simplified things for her. But, I should ask her if that upset her. She doesn't know I avoided inviting friends over because I was embarrassed. I haven't shared that with her.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: I joined the Hapa club in school, a group for mixed race people. Even though I'm not mixed race, I felt drawn to it. Joining this club and meeting others passionate about their cultures helped me appreciate my Asian heritage. In my sophomore year, all my roommates were Asian, and many of their friends were from an Asian fraternity. My suite mate was second-generation Hong Kongese who, like me, grew up in a predominantly white area. Discussing our experiences and complexities of our cultural identities was eye-opening. One day, I passionately spoke to her about the greatness of being Asian, which she still remembers to this day.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: My dad's definition of success for his children changed around the time we graduated college. He became extremely supportive of our career paths and interests. He celebrated when I expressed interest in becoming an acupuncturist, a psychologist, an occupational therapist, and even when I wanted to pursue design. My dad was under immense stress when starting his business and projected his pressures onto my brother and me. He felt obligated to achieve a certain level of success due to the opportunities his father provided him with, including studying in the US. This expectation extended to us as well. However, once he achieved financial success, he realized it wasn't the most important thing in life. This realization led him to shift his parenting perspective as we became adults, becoming more open-minded and supportive of different career paths.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Recently, my brother and I discussed the pressure we felt to achieve conventional success. This could be subconsciously related to our upbringing. There was an underlying notion that we'd end up homeless or in low-paying jobs if we didn't work hard, earn a lot of money, or attend a good college. There's a certain pressure to be financially successful.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Growing up, my parents were rather strict, especially regarding academics. They invested a lot in our education, including tutoring in various subjects, particularly math and science. My father emphasized financial success, which instilled a sense of urgency in us to work hard. They often warned us that without hard work, we might end up homeless or in low-paying jobs, a common sentiment among immigrant parents.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Once I got to college, I finally felt happy being Asian. I stopped trying so hard to fit in because I was exposed to many different kinds of people. It was a work in progress, moving from a childhood of trying to blend into a predominantly white society to realizing I didn't have to. This prompted a journey of self-discovery, questioning my identity and feelings about my cultural heritage.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: As I'm getting older, I realize parents do the best they can with the information they have at the moment. They wanted me to have a good education and believed going to a Catholic school was the way to achieve that. The result was living in a predominantly white area. I don't question their choices. If anything, these experiences have hopefully made me a stronger person.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: That's an interesting question. I've never thought much about it. My parents always presented my "whitewashing" as positive, which might have ingrained subconsciously in me that it's a good thing. Despite everything that happened, I don't view the experience negatively, which might be concerning.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: In high school, my best friend was Korean. We both desperately sought to fit in, often downplaying our own vulnerabilities. When I attempted to discuss feelings of difference, she would deny experiencing the same. We were both guarded, likely grappling with similar struggles but never openly addressing them. We stuck together, united by our shared Asian identity, but never fully expressed our feelings due to our mutual pursuit of assimilation.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: People often ridiculed me, even for my choice of underwear. I felt unwelcome in the dance group due to the girls' unkindness, leading me to quit. There's no question, my school life was filled with many embarrassing moments. I constantly felt embarrassed growing up.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: I loved dance. I used to figure skate as well. High school was tough because I enjoyed dance and wanted to be part of that group. Unfortunately, people would make comments like, "Do you go home and eat dogs?"
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Growing up, I loved to draw, but when people commented that my art looked very Asian, I felt embarrassed. Consequently, I would change my drawing style to avoid any specific Asian style. In high school, I strove to fit in, even forcing myself to enjoy TV shows and topics I had no interest in. I recall that people implied Asian guys weren't attractive, and fearing mockery, I'd suppress any attraction I had towards Asian guys. Ultimately, I was driven by a strong desire to fit in.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: In college, a friend expressed her love for Japanese culture and her desire for half Asian children, but she didn't want them to look half Japanese, fearing they would be unattractive. This, along with other comments, built up in my subconscious, making me believe that being Asian was less attractive and that white features were more desirable. Even my parents would comment that bigger eyes were more attractive, and being "whitewashed" and appearing mixed was seen as a positive. They were pleased that I could assimilate within the culture and communicate with white people, given that I attended a predominantly white school.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: I first recognized the white standard of beauty in middle school. I attended an integrated elementary school where I didn't feel different. It wasn't until I moved to a Catholic middle school in fourth grade that I understood I was Asian and different. Little comments, not necessarily derogatory, made me feel different, like a friend suggesting my vision was bad because my eyes were small due to my Asian heritage.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: I felt uncomfortable inviting friends over, fearing mockery over our Asian artwork or the smell of my mom's cooking. People also made comments that affected my self-perception, saying things like, "You're pretty for an Asian," prompting me to associate beauty with white standards.
Adolescence.concept: Asian stereotype, cultural pride, racial identity
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: I was also embarrassed to be Asian, such as when a cheerleading teammate asked if my family ate dogs because we're Chinese. I also faced ignorance about Taiwan, leading me to tell people I was Chinese.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: A common experience in my generation was embarrassment over our culture's food. My mom packed Japanese and Taiwanese lunches for me, and I felt uncomfortable because people thought the food smelled strange. So, I requested peanut butter sandwich instead. Interestingly, today's younger generations see Asian food as cool. Growing up, I attended a predominantly white school, feeling like an outsider as one of the few Asians. If my mom called, I wouldn't speak Mandarin to avoid mockery.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: My mom primarily speaks Mandarin, occasionally using a few English words. My dad speaks more English but still mostly Mandarin. He used to travel a lot to China for his business, but now he's semi-retired and works remotely. I struggle with Mandarin because I only speak it when I interact with my parents, which isn't often, resulting in my Mandarin skills weakening.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: 「The fact that we were all Asian mattered more to me than my mentees. To me, Asian American was a messy, arbitrary category, but one that was produced by a collective struggle. It was a category capacious enough for all of our hopes and energies.」
Adolescence.concept: Asian American experience, cultural pride, racial identity
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「I took as many ethnic studies and Asian American studies classes as I could, immersing myself in the traditions that had preceded us. It gave me solace to root around in the past and wonder if some of these moments of solidarity and action could find new spark with our generation. Out of principle, I stopped reading fiction. I wanted to learn only about histories that had been denied to us.」
Adolescence.concept: Asian American experience, identity questioning, personal implications
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: "I think like right now with the coronavirus, I think we’re just Chinese, Chinese American, well, just Asian American or Asians in general, you’re just going through the same struggles right now. Like everyone is just blaming whoever looks Asian about the virus. You don’t feel safe.”
Adolescence.Contributor: U.S.-born man of Chinese origin in early 30s
Adolescence.title: What It Means To Be Asian in America

Adolescence.content: "“I find that there’s a, ‘So but where are you from?’ Like even in professional settings when they feel comfortable enough to ask you. ‘So – so where are you from?’ ‘Oh, I was born in [names city], Colorado. Like at [the hospital], down the street.’ ‘No, but like where are you from?’ ‘My mother’s womb?’”
Adolescence.Contributor: U.S.-born woman of Indian origin in early 40s
Adolescence.title: What It Means To Be Asian in America

Adolescence.content: "“I always get that question of, you know, ‘Where are you from?’ and I’m like, ‘I’m from America.’ And then they’re like, ‘No. Where are you from-from?’ and I’m like, ‘Yeah, my family is from Pakistan,’ so it’s like I always had like that dual identity even though it’s never attached to me because I am like, of Pakistani descent.”
Adolescence.Contributor: U.S.-born man of Pakistani origin in early 20s
Adolescence.title: What It Means To Be Asian in America

Adolescence.content: "“So basically, all I know is that I was born in the United States. Again, when I came back, I didn’t feel any barrier with my other friends who are White or Black. … Then I got a little confused in high school when I had trouble self-identifying if I am Asian, Chinese American, like who am I. … Should I completely immerse myself in the American culture? Should I also keep my Chinese identity and stuff like that? So yeah, that was like the middle of that mist. Now, I’m pretty clear about myself. I think I am Chinese American, Asian American, whatever people want.”
Adolescence.Contributor: U.S.-born woman of Chinese origin in early 20s
Adolescence.title: What It Means To Be Asian in America

Adolescence.content: "As a woman or being a girl, because of your gender, you have to keep your mouth shut [and] wait so that they call on you for you to speak up. … I do respect our elders and I do respect hearing their guidance but I also want them to learn to hear from the younger person … because we have things to share that they might not know and that [are] important … so I like to challenge gender roles or traditional roles because it is something that [because] I was born and raised here [in America], I learn that we all have the equal rights to be able to speak and share our thoughts and ideas.”
Adolescence.Contributor: U.S.-born woman of Cambodian origin in mid-30s
Adolescence.title: What It Means To Be Asian in America

Adolescence.content: “I feel like one of the biggest things I’ve seen, just like [my] Asian American friends overall, is the kind of family-individualistic clash … like wanting to do your own thing is like, is kind of instilled in you as an American, like go and … follow your dream. But then you just grow up with such a sense of like also wanting to be there for your family and to live up to those expectations, and I feel like that’s something that’s very pronounced in Asian cultures.”
Adolescence.Contributor: U.S.-born man of Indian origin in mid-20s
Adolescence.title: What It Means To Be Asian in America

Adolescence.content: “Being bi-ethnic and tri-cultural creates so many unique dynamics, and … one of the dynamics has to do with … what it is to be Americanized. … One of the things that played a role into how I associate the identity is language. Now, my father never spoke Spanish to me … because he wanted me to develop a fluency in English, because for him, he struggled with English. What happened was three out of the four people that raised me were Khmer … they spoke to me in Khmer. We’d eat breakfast, lunch and dinner speaking Khmer. We’d go to the temple in Khmer with the language and we’d also watch videos and movies in Khmer. … Looking into why I strongly identify with the heritage, one of the reasons is [that] speaking that language connects to the home I used to have [as my families have passed away].”
Adolescence.Contributor: U.S.-born man of Cambodian origin in early 30s
Adolescence.title: What It Means To Be Asian in America

Adolescence.content: “I guess … I feel like I just kind of check off ‘Asian’ [for] an application or the test forms. That’s the only time I would identify as Asian. But Asian is too broad. Asia is a big continent. Yeah, I feel like it’s just too broad. To specify things, you’re Taiwanese American, that’s exactly where you came from.”
Adolescence.concept: Asian, ethnicity, racial identity, racial representation
Adolescence.Contributor: U.S.-born woman of Taiwanese origin in early 20s
Adolescence.title: What It Means To Be Asian in America

Adolescence.content: 「“Zines are a metaphor for life,” I wrote in the welcome note. “It’s your creation and your voice and your life… a form of expression that can be perverted by nobody and accepted/ hated by everybody… Create, destroy, and subvert.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「There was a page listing my favorite websites (“ terrific Karl Marx site,” “live Pavement recordings, all RealAudio”), stories from the Oakland warehouse raves where I’d go and dance by myself, dispatches from an Asian American film festival I’d covered for my newspaper internship, a poem by a beautiful skater girl I’d met through Anthony.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: Indeed, I fit the stereotype being good at math while growing up, but I wasn't very proficient in other sciences like physics or biology. When choosing a college and career, I followed my interests, not feeling forced into a path I didn't want to pursue. While not everything aligned with my desires, I enjoyed the learning process. As I explored more in college and adulthood, I catered to my preferences.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: There are many stereotypes that Asian Americans try to break. The most common ones include being good at math, science, computers, or playing video games all the time. A lot of Asian Americans are trying to break away from this by pursuing diverse interests, such as sports or creative hobbies. Some parents often encouraged us to excel in school, specifically in math, science, or musical instruments like piano or violin. This expectation sometimes restricts many Asian Americans from exploring other creative outlets. As we grow up, we start to realize the variety of things we can do. For me, it was sports like running and basketball. There are so many opportunities available nowadays for self-exploration and breaking stereotypes.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: That's a good question. Pinpointing a specific moment when I questioned my American or Asian American identity is challenging. It's a realization that occurred over several years, influenced by my experiences. Whether it was comments made by others, conversations with my brother, tasks my parents needed me to do, or stories shared by people with similar experiences, these elements cumulatively shaped my identity. It's not an isolated identity crisis, but rather a universal phenomenon. Many Asian Americans share similar experiences and upbringings. You start to see patterns and realize that others have had similar journeys. These reflections often happen during high school or college when you question your identity and upbringing. However, it's not just one thing that defines this process but a myriad of experiences throughout my life.
Adolescence.concept: adolescence, identity crisis, similar experiences, universal phenomenon
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Sure, many people ask, "Where are you from?" and even after I reply, "From the U.S." they follow up with, "Where are you actually from?" It's an assumption that I wasn't born here, even though I was. People usually expect me to say "China" when they inquire about my cultural identity. This happens frequently, based on appearances. I believe many Asian Americans born here have had similar experiences.
Adolescence.concept: Asian American experience, cultural difference, racial identity
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: There were instances of stereotypes and bullying due to my Asian American background. These incidents were sporadic, often in the form of verbal messages or interactions. Derogatory terms, like chink were sometimes used during basketball games. The impact of these words was more profound during childhood. It felt as though I was being judged by my appearance. While some might see these remarks as jokes, they generally conveyed a negative message. As a child, I felt a sense of embarrassment due to these experiences. It wasn't just about how I looked but also about my culture, the food I ate, and things associated with me. But now, I'm proud of my appearance and my culture.
Adolescence.concept: Asian American experience, stereotype, verbal discrimination
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Building relationships and friendships through playing basketball was crucial for me. It strengthened my connection with my family. Even though we don't play as much now, we remain close. Part of this closeness is due to our shared love for basketball, a common language that brought us together. Following sports teams like the Washington Wizards also exposed me to other sports such as baseball, football, and soccer. Engaging in these Americanized sports helped me better adjust to the culture around me and resonate more with kids growing up in the same environment.
Adolescence.concept: Americanized, basketball, connection, culture, family, sports
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Reflecting on my parents' qualities, they were relaxed and recognized our need to adapt to our environment, which included speaking more English. However, we still attended a weekend Chinese school to learn Mandarin, despite struggling to fully grasp it. They offered other classes there, but it was primarily for Mandarin, not Cantonese. Cantonese isn't popular in the area where we lived.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Regarding lunch preparation, we chose what we wanted to bring to school, which differed from the norm. My parents understood, recognizing that our experiences were distinct from theirs. They acknowledged our need to fit in through aspects such as food choices, assimilating with what other kids brought to school.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Indeed, we could relate to what you're talking about. My brothers and I often brought more westernized foods to school, such as peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, though these weren't typical at home meals. We also favored things like Lunchables, pre-prepared meals from grocery stores that were popular among kids. However, back then, we often felt embarrassed to bring lunch box with Asian food to school, a sentiment that has changed significantly today. When asked about the sense of embarrassment, it was more prominent during high school. We tended to bring more westernized food to fit in with our peers and see what they were bringing to school.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Growing up, I was fortunate to have a lot of exposure to various experiences from my elementary school years and upbringing. I found commonalities with my peers through shared interests, such as sports or school activities. We also bonded over similar experiences, like having the same teachers, navigating the same academic challenges, or pursuing similar paths in high school or careers. One of my closest friends in middle school and elementary school, who was also Asian, shared a passion for basketball. These commonalities throughout childhood really bring people together.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: I enjoyed playing basketball and video games during school. Some of my close friends and I formed a high school basketball league. We played weekly games. Even though we never won a championship, we had a lot of fun. We made our own team and played a lot outside of school. My friends were diverse with Asian, Indian, Korean, and even Black backgrounds.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: Absolutely, he did and still does guide us in many ways. My elder brother took on the responsibility of navigating us through aspects of life that our parents, due to their unfamiliarity with the system here, couldn't advise on. I think that's an accurate depiction of his role. We attended the same schools from elementary through high school. Even in college, despite being on opposite coasts, I continued to seek his advice. I reached out for his guidance, a practice that didn't stop after high school.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: We didn't often eat pasta, but we frequently enjoyed Asian food, particularly Chinese. We cherished home-cooked meals, particularly dishes like dumplings, rice meals, and noodle dishes. My favorite is the popular Cantonese dish, egg with tomato, which my dad often prepared. We also had a variety of foods from different cuisines, like Korean and Thai. Overall, my palate leaned heavily towards Asian cuisine.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: We primarily celebrated holidays like the Lunar New Year, significant in our culture. Celebrations usually involved family gatherings or dinners. Instead of conventional gifts, we received red envelopes on birthdays and holidays. These occasions were often marked by cooking and enjoying food together. My dad, a restaurant chef, had a passion for cooking. He often tried new recipes, resulting in a plethora of home-cooked Chinese meals. To me, the meanings of red envelope vary by location, but it's largely about good luck, health, and positive energy. Receiving it from parents, uncles, aunts, or grandparents feels significant. To boil it down, it signifies good health, luck, and positive energy.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content: That's a great question, it brings back fond memories. As kids, we'd fight occasionally but mostly for fun. We learned and grew from each other. An example would be playing basketball or going to the park to chat about our day. Since my older brother is only a year older, we went to the same schools and had similar experiences. Growing up in the states, having an older brother who had gone through things first was beneficial. He provided inspiration and a roadmap. With our parents being immigrants from China, they had less understanding of the education system here. However, having an older brother who went through it before me provided insights that helped me navigate school and my career after graduation.
Adolescence.title: Thesis Interviewee

Adolescence.content:
「For a while, I thought Ken bore a striking resemblance to Henry Cho, a Korean American comedian I’d seen doing stand-up on cable. Cho had an easy, accommodating smile and a singsong drawl. His shtick was that he was an observational comic and that these observations came from an Asian man in the South. Cheerful, self-effacing replies to casual racism.」

—Stay True: A Memoir (Pulitzer Prize Winner)，作者：Hua Hsu
https://a.co/doCtsHA

“Growing up, Japanese Americans suggested a strange model of who all of us newer immigrants might become, a stepping-stone, generations into the future, toward some effortless sense of belonging.”

— Stay True: A Memoir (Pulitzer Prize Winner) by Hua Hsu
https://a.co/6SNGRMp

“We were both Asian, conscious of all the stereotypes about being low maintenance and good at school. Yet we had come from such different worlds. I remember how odd it was that he sometimes forgot to take his shoes off when he came over.”

— Stay True: A Memoir (Pulitzer Prize Winner) by Hua Hsu
https://a.co/dAjrBAw

“People began attacking one another, drawing a line in the sand between Black and white. It was as if he were describing some dramatic bar brawl. “This white chick started crying,” he said, and then more people started crying. It was unclear where he stood in this conversation, if anyone noticed him to begin with. Quotations about complicity, victimhood, and color-blind racism were lobbed across the room, accusations flew inches from his face, and he was in the middle of it, neither Black nor white, scrutinizing the gestures and details that nobody else picked up on.”

— Stay True: A Memoir (Pulitzer Prize Winner) by Hua Hsu

I had experienced that as a kid with my father, where I was ashamed of my dad for yelling at someone that hurled an epitaph at us. And I don’t know why I did that and I was too young. But there’s a moment like that in the film, where Ember was denied going to see a flower because the fire was too dangerous, and it connected to something that was this emotional moment, where Wade brings her through this miracle of fake science, of bringing air down there for her to breathe and see the wisteria flower for the first time.
Adolescence.title: Peter Sohn Revisits The Emotional Box Office Comeback Of 'Elemental' [Interview]

Adolescence.content:
I hadn’t thought about it that way. I was a very naive and jerk kid to my parents, because growing up in that world I didn’t realize how hard it is. When my parents were telling me their stories of having survived the Korean War or they had nothing, I would say, “OK, can I play video games now?” I was that type of kid. 

The older I got, it started to sink in. How did they do this without knowing the language? When I got married and had kids, it started to dig into me about how much I appreciated what they had given. So, that opening was to show how hard it was for them, as outsiders coming into this new world.
Adolescence.title: ‘Elemental’ Director Peter Sohn on How the Periodic Table and His Parents’ Immigration Story Inspired Pixar’s Latest Feature

Adolescence.content: Now, at 23 years old, Daignault finally understands the important things she lost along with her mother tongue: a connection to her culture, a sense of belonging and even the confidence to identify as an ethnic woman.
Adolescence.title: Preserving mother tongues: Why children of immigrants are losing their languages

Adolescence.content: As second-generation immigrants, we try to navigate life with intense pressure to fit in, all the while trying to stay connected to our roots despite the overwhelming fear of being judged. We learn just how impossible it is to live up to our parents' expectations and to overcome the image society has of immigrants.
Adolescence.title: A third culture: Navigating second-generation identity

Adolescence.content: As I grew older, I met more of my extended family, having titas and titos (aunts and uncles for Filipinos) come over more often, I started to develop this sense of belonging that I once yearned for.
Adolescence.title: A third culture: Navigating second-generation identity

Adolescence.content: According to a 2016 census by https://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2016/as-sa/98-200-x/2016017/98-200-x2016017-eng.cfm, 16.9 percent of immigrants are reported to only know English and 59.6 per cent to know English and at least one other language. Oftentimes I wished my parents could have done more and encouraged me to learn, but I now know my parents only stripped me of my ancestry out of necessity. To survive, they, along with my sister and I, had to conform to western society.
Adolescence.title: A third culture: Navigating second-generation identity

Adolescence.content: “If you came back, you wanted to leave again. If you went away, you wanted to come back. Wherever you were, you could hear the call of the homeland, like the note of a herdsman’s horn. Far away in the hills, You had one home out there and one over here, And yet, you were an alien in both places. Your true abiding place was the vision of something very far off And your soul was like the waves, always restless, forever in motion, Never at home.” “Only those who risk going too far can possibly find out how far they can go.”
Adolescence.title: The Emigrants (POEM)

Adolescence.content: “Stood out in school, you’re the new girl from overseas, definitely a slap in the face. Went back to Korea, preteen years, sixth to eighth grades, I had a hard time fitting in overseas, all were Asian and I was still white American.”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “Like a home, home is where the heart is, no matter where I am or move to, PR is my home.”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “At first, like a tree, rooted and connected and family were the branches. But now, like a fly, having a desire for freedom.”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “Like a teenager in an American high school cafeteria, filled with all its different groups. TCKs fit in with all groups, going from one to the next, knowing how to adapt and relate to differences (in schools) yet not fitting in to any.”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “Like a beacon, draws me back. I feel like a global chameleon, I blend into my surroundings, adjust to cultures, don’t change my personality, but may have an external look.”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “Van Reken explained, “in one airplane ride, my world was gone; no way to say good-bye to my home” (personal communication, August 2001).”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “I now relate to and associate with people like I’ve always been here in the United States. But when I meet someone with a similar background, I remember how different my life was and the ease and naturalness of relating to that person, I have a sense of belonging with that person.”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “I noticed probably in elementary school in Puerto Rico that I was different. The other kids didn’t look like me; they called me “gringo,” and I was the only one leaving to go to the United States every summer and Christmas.”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “When I moved back to Korea in the middle of sixth grade, I lived overseas again and I knew I was different. I sensed “something” in the second and third grade too. Also, when I left Turkey rather quickly and returned to NC for a year in high school, I knew I was different.”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: ““TCK life helped me experience everything life has to offer, made life easier moving so much. First-hand living in the culture, you could not help growing up quicker.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: ““teachers overseas made you feel comfortable, took the time to build relationships with me and my family.” EE expressed, “I experienced this all throughout U.S. schools, cultural sensitivity is really lacking in the United States.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: ““in my college Asian Culture class, my professor used my experiences from having lived in three countries in Asia, it complemented his teaching and gave credibility to what he was saying in class.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: ““U.S. teachers thought I was strange, they had small town mentality. Overseas teachers were intrigued with me and me with them so we connected better.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “Coupland’s (1994) Life After God book: Home to me, as I have said, is a shared electronic dream of cartoon memories, half-hour sitcoms and national tragedies. I realized my accent was simply the accent of nowhere, the accent of a person who has no fixed home in his mind. (p. 94)”
Adolescence.title: Life After God

Adolescence.content: ““I knew the teachers as I grew up with them because my parents were also teachers there. Teachers were used to mobility of students and related well to their students; they were used to building a common bridge for all students there. Teachers took an interest in your life.” As a TCK, “I am open-minded and understanding because of this experience, and my social and personal skills are successful because of it. My experience was easier because I had two older sisters and caring parents.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “Growing up in a culture that is very accepting. I bought into Puerto Rican culture and was accepted as Puerto Rican, even though I was born in an American family. But at times, it was also challenging as not everyone accepted me even though I was born in Puerto Rico.”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: ““You mature quicker and are more independent; whereas the most challenging experience was coming to the United States and getting acquainted to schools, respect from teachers and being treated as a foreigner.” “Overseas, teachers were pretty good because they were around TCKs a lot; so we were the norm there.” Although EE experienced much back and forth in schooling, it is hard for him to remember the interactions at an early age. “When you meet a TCK, it feels good. There tends to be more of an instant connection, connections that tend to last a lifetime.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: ““You never feel like you have a home, long-term friends and roots, but I wouldn’t change that. Starting school over and over was hard in new places.” BM’s most memorable schooling experiences overseas were in the Welsh schools, “strict discipline, sit up straight! and tapping you on the shoulder with a ruler, but they were constructivists and believed in wholistic education. However, in high school, I could not relate to British teachers and they yelled at us, even told us to shut up.” She has fond memories of her DODEA teachers;”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “Her definition of a TCK is An American child who grew up overseas, attending American schools overseas; not really an American kid, not really part of the other culture, in your own little world. But, I related to things differently, educational experiences and background were different. Being a TCK is “an opportunity of a lifetime!” Later on in life, reflecting on this lived experience, BM stated, “it is life-altering, seeing different ways of doing things, perceiving things differently. It completely defines you, separates you from those in the states. There are a million different ways to look at things.” BM’s most meaningful experiences were getting to travel to many places, living in other cultures, independence, and speaking other languages. Her most challenging experience was “settling down (between moves) with people and connections, then being ripped up and starting all over again.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: ““Being a TCK makes me feel instant connections when I meet another TCK. Being an only child with only one parent made a big impact on my life, and I had a lot of independence.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “AM attended many different kinds of schools within the DODEA system. Of her time in the Philippines, Korea, Turkey, and Japan, AM liked Korea best because she felt the programs and schooling were most like the U.S.”
Adolescence.concept: TCK, cultural difference, third culture kids
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: ““I’m home overseas, not a place in general, it’s a feeling. I want to go back overseas, it’s like a beacon.”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: ““we were very independent at young ages with taking local transportation. We had free rein by our parents. Our parents let us be independent. We would catch flights by ourselves (when we lived in Europe).””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: ““you never feel like you have a home, roots, but I wouldn’t change that.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: ““The hardest for me was everyone didn’t live like we did. As a child, I thought everyone did this. As I got older, I thought this isn’t normal; but others thought I was fortunate.” This back and forth mobility lifestyle to New York caused TW to miss his friends in Puerto Rico, especially during summer vacation from school. “It was hectic trying to stay connected to friends in Puerto Rico and family in New York.”
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “When EE returned to his birthplace, Okinawa, at the end of his senior year of high school, he remarked, “I had this feeling as if I was home. Living in the States had its pros and cons. But living near my grandparents in the United States for a few years was the one constant in my life, a form of stability!””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “Relationships also played a key role in BM’s life; her twin sister is her best friend. BM describes her as “the consistent person in my life, she experienced what I experienced and shared the same feelings.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “As a matter of fact, “all the moves were hard on me especially with social issues.” Familial relationships were key in AM’s back and forth life. “Now, my mom is my best friend. Early in life I resented her, but now I appreciate her and my TCK life.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: “Although AM lives in North Carolina, she explained, “I’m thinking of moving again! Each culture made me realize how different my life was.””
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content:
There is this cultural difference coming from overseas to the United States for schooling (as a TCK). You experience a lot of stereotypes. From my experiences in U.S. schools, teachers did not use my overseas experiences as lessons in the classrooms. There was an ignorance from teachers (particularly in high school) about cultures, especially Asian, and stereotypes of those cultures. Teachers were not welcoming to (curriculum) options other than what was written in textbooks. They did not use students as curriculum resources in learning. In the younger grades, I did not understand what was going on. But by eighth grade, I realized
that in general “something was missing” in my (U.S.) schooling experiences. I suppose a lot depends on the demographics of the school, community and teachers’ backgrounds as well as teachers’ knowledge of their students. Growing up in this (TCK) life and building trust with teachers is so important.
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: My home is everywhere but nowhere; the world is my home.
Adolescence.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Adolescence.content: They don’t have Scottish accents but they don’t have American accents, they’re kind of in the middle. They are in this fluid state of feeling at home wherever they are, and always being a little bit homesick for somewhere else
Adolescence.title: The best books on Third Culture Kids

Adolescence.content: 「I had some concert bootlegs where it sounded as if someone had thrown a heavy blanket over Kurt Cobain’s microphone. But these performances were urgent and crisp. I was amazed that there could be even more Nirvana in the world. I’d moved on from them at the apex of their fame. Now that they were no longer as popular as when I was in high school, I felt a nostalgic fondness for these songs.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「School was easy and I was surrounded by people who liked or at least tolerated me. But I was stridently noncommittal to them. I always left myself an out, an escape hatch in case someone offered me a new adventure, the adventure I thought I deserved.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「Why did I insist on being so weird? What compelled me to always order the most unusual item on the menu? Wasn’t it all a ploy to be noticed by others? Especially, he would say accusingly, “artsy, alternative” girls? And hadn’t I briefly owned the first Pearl Jam album, too?」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: Later still, I came to recognize that assimilation as a whole was a race toward a horizon that wasn’t fixed. The ideal was ever shifting, and your accent would never be quite perfect. It was a set of compromises sold to you as a contract. Assimilation was not a problem to be solved but the problem itself.
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: Cobain had been representative of something, but maybe not something of which I felt a part. He was outside the system, only I felt further outside it. I faxed my dad the night it happened. I couldn’t understand Cobain’s death by suicide.
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「I was matriculating into a world of abundance, where there was at least three of everything—used bookstores, record stores, vintage boutiques—within a four-block radius. I was an American child, and I was bored, and I was searching for my people.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「I was sixteen, and I wanted to be carried away. I would leave for college the next fall. I fantasized about going somewhere strange and new. Los Angeles wasn’t far enough. San Diego was lame. Seattle was far enough but in a useless direction. I didn’t like the idea of being landlocked. I felt too young for New York. Boston was lame, too. I was drawn to Johns Hopkins until I realized I wouldn’t be nearly as enamored with a school called “John Hopkins.”」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「A couple weeks later, I faxed my dad a copy of an article I wrote for the school paper about Cobain’s death and what it said about our generation. I was using the term loosely, since Cobain was ten years older than me. I believed there was something exceptional about our time, the pressures we faced, the struggles to remain content in aimless times.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「Like millions of other people, my first glimpse into the prospect of “alternative” culture came when I listened to Nirvana’s “Smells Like Teen Spirit” in 1991. I was thirteen. It was one of the greatest songs I had ever heard, mostly because it was the first great song I had chosen on my own.」
Adolescence.concept: alternative culture, music choice, personal preference
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「There comes a moment for the immigrant’s child when you realize that you and your parents are assimilating at the same time…Later still, I came to recognize that assimilation as a whole was a race toward a horizon that wasn’t fixed. The ideal was ever shifting, and your accent would never be quite perfect. It was a set of compromises sold to you as a contract. Assimilation was not a problem to be solved but the problem itself.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「But one day, you realize that your parents speak with a mild accent, and that they have no idea what passive voice is. The next generation would acquire a skill on their behalf—one that we could also use against them. Commanding the language seemed like our only way of surpassing them.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「On weekends, my parents drove to Taipei to seek out old tea shops and movie theaters they remembered from the 1950s and 1960s. They didn’t need maps. Decades away hadn’t dulled their memory of which stalls served the best baos. My parents grew younger in Taiwan; the humidity and food turned them into different people. I sometimes felt like an interloper as we sat on weathered, wooden stools and silently ate giant bowls of beef noodles that, were this America, would have prompted a romantic soliloquy about their childhood memories.」
Adolescence.title: Review of Fresh off the boat

Adolescence.content: 「The first generation thinks about survival; the ones that follow tell the stories.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「I sometimes ran into classmates at the airport and realized that we were all there to drop our dads off at work.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「Once I started middle school, I realized that my dad’s record buying had prepared me for the social hierarchies of recess.」
「Immigrants are often discussed in terms of a push-and-pull dynamic: something pushes you from home; something else pulls you far away.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「In fact, I was very bad at math. Like many immigrants who prized education, my parents retained faith in the mastery of technical fields, like the sciences, where answers weren’t left to interpretation. You couldn’t discriminate against the right answer. But I preferred to spend my time interpreting things.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「WHEN MY FATHER MOVED to Taiwan, my family bought a pair of fax machines. In theory, this was so he could help me with my math homework. I was starting high school, where everything, from what instrument I played to the well roundedness of my transcript, suddenly seemed consequential.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: 「The leap from sophomore to junior year of college suggested unprecedented new heights of poise and maturity. Back then, your emotions were always either very high or very low, unless you were bored, and nobody in human history had ever been this bored before.」
Adolescence.title: Stay True

Adolescence.content: "“I switched from a school with a super welcoming new student program to a school where I was the first new kid in years,” she says. “Everyone knew everyone and no one knew me. [They were] in a bubble and being friends with the new girl from Amsterdam who didn't necessarily understand American fashion, and allegedly had an accent, was not one of their priorities.”"
Adolescence.title: Third Culture Kids: Citizens of everywhere and nowhere

Adolescence.content: "“It’s definitely a lot easier [moving to] an international school because everyone’s in the same boat,” her son Chris recalls of that time. “Making friends when I moved back to Aberdeen at 16 was the hardest because everyone else there had been at school together since primary.”"
Adolescence.title: Third Culture Kids: Citizens of everywhere and nowhere

Adolescence.content: Home is ‘everywhere and nowhere’
Adolescence.title: Third Culture Kids: Citizens of everywhere and nowhere

Adolescence.content: we aren't different enough to be loathed. We are in a perpetually grey zone, and society isn't quite sure what to do with us.
Adolescence.title: I Am Not Your Asian Stereotype | Canwen Xu | TEDxBoise

Adolescence.content: For my fourteenth birthday, I received the video game The Sim3, which lets you create your own characters and control their lives. My fourteen-year-old self created the perfect little mainstream family, complete with a huge mansion and an enormous swimming pool. I binge-played the game for about three months, then put it away and never really thought about it again, until a few weeks ago, when I came to a sudden realization. The family, that I had custom-designed, was white.
Adolescence.concept: character diversity, racial customization, racial representation
Adolescence.title: I Am Not Your Asian Stereotype | Canwen Xu | TEDxBoise

Adolescence.content: I felt like a stranger in my own country living a way has also made me feel a bit distant with my relatives who all live thousands of kilometers away although I did speak to them via Skype it was not the same as spending time with them in person the language barrier when first moving can make you feel very confused and isolated as well
Adolescence.title: I Am Not Your Asian Stereotype | Canwen Xu | TEDxBoise

Young adulthood.content:
“What we’re looking for isn’t available at a Trader Joe’s. H Mart is where your people gather under one odorous roof, full of faith that they’ll find something they can’t find anywhere else.”

— Crying in H Mart: A Memoir by Michelle Zauner
https://a.co/dQ6QRKT
Young adulthood.title: Crying in H Mart: A Memoir

Young adulthood.content:
“We were editors for Hardboiled, the college Asian American newspaper. At our first meeting of the year, the staff shared story ideas—a retrospective of the Yellow Power movement, the experience of Hmong and Mien kids in the East Bay, sweatshop labor in the Pacific Islands, campus turntablists, the enigma of Asian American conservatives, the subversive politics of lowered Acuras, modified Integras, and street racing.”

— Stay True: A Memoir (Pulitzer Prize Winner) by Hua Hsu
https://a.co/bji1Cd5
Young adulthood.concept: Asian American experience, Pulitzer Prize Winner, memoir
Young adulthood.title: Stay True

Young adulthood.content: 「There were similarities that cut across nationality and class: the uncommunicative parents, the cultural significance of food, the fact that we all took our shoes off at home. Our young mentees just had to realize such a community was for them, too.」
Young adulthood.title: Stay True

Young adulthood.content: "Yeah, I want to say that’s how I feel – because like thinking about it, I would call my dad Lao but I would call myself Laotian American because I think I’m a little more integrated in the American society and I’ve also been a little more Americanized, compared to my dad. So that’s how I would see it.”
Young adulthood.concept: Americanized, assimilation, cultural, ethnicity, identity, language, second generation immigrant
Young adulthood.Contributor: U.S.-born man of Laotian origin in late 20s
Young adulthood.title: What It Means To Be Asian in America

Young adulthood.content: “I would also say [that I am] Indian American just because I find myself always bouncing between the two … it’s not even like dual identity, it just is one whole identity for me, like there’s not this separation. … I’m doing [both] Indian things [and] American things. … They use that term like ABCD … ‘American Born Confused Desi’ … I don’t feel that way anymore, although there are those moments … but I would say [that I am] Indian American for sure.”
Young adulthood.concept: Americanized, Asian, Asian stereotype, cultural, diversity, ethnicity, identity, identity crisis, language, racial customization, racial identity, racial representation, representation, second generation immigrant, stereotype, third culture kids
Young adulthood.Contributor: U.S.-born woman of Indian origin in early 30s
Young adulthood.title: What It Means To Be Asian in America

Young adulthood.content: Jeremy Lin is a significant figure for many Asian Americans, breaking numerous stereotypes as one of the first Asian American NBA players to make a substantial impact. He's a role model to many, including myself, due to his community contributions and trailblazing achievements. Regardless of your background, his story surpasses expectations. He has made a lasting impact and continues to be popular today. I've watched many of his games and still enjoy his highlights. He also openly acknowledges his heritage, which is an important part of his story. It's commendable that he shares this, as many people, whether from Taiwan or the States, can relate to it.
Young adulthood.concept: racial identity, racial representation, role models
Young adulthood.title: Thesis Interviewee

Young adulthood.content: It was indeed helpful having an older brother. Similarly, my younger brother, who used to be a bit of a goofball, has matured significantly. We looked to each other for assistance and guidance. He's an intelligent younger brother and I'm fortunate to have grown up with two wonderful brothers. If time permits, I have plenty of shared stories to tell.
Young adulthood.title: Thesis Interviewee

Young adulthood.content: “A fly—what? They have a two-day lifespan? Desire to see as much as you can while I’m still young with no children, freedom! I can tell you this though . . . when I was younger, probably a Tree, want to be rooted, connections, and branches as my family. Now, not so much, I have as an adult connected with my family so I don’t need that so much. I want freedom now!”
Young adulthood.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Young adulthood.content: “T. S. Eliot’s (as quoted in Denzin & Lincoln, 2003b, p. 71) Little Giddings, last of the Four Quartets : We shall not cease from exploration And the end of all our exploring Will be to arrive where we started And know the place for the first time.””
Young adulthood.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Young adulthood.content: “I was a little familiar with life in the United States because of every summer and Christmas and being with family in New York. But there would have been a major social change from Puerto Rico to the United States without this back ’n’ forth life every year.”
Young adulthood.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Young adulthood.content: ““When I started to go to college in North Carolina, I started to ‘fit in’ and felt ‘normal.’ I am adjusted now but am rearing to go back.””
Young adulthood.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Young adulthood.content: ““I wouldn’t be who I am without these TCK experiences. My entire family, we are all travelers, it’s all about family. The TCK life helped me experience everything life has to offer.””
Young adulthood.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND

Young adulthood.content:
「We agreed to meet for a weekly, late-night dinner at Orchid, a Chinese restaurant a few blocks away from our dorm. It reminded me of family meals at home.」

—Stay True: A Memoir (Pulitzer Prize Winner)，作者：Hua Hsu
https://a.co/a7MMdPc
Young adulthood.title: Stay True

Young adulthood.content: 「Maybe this was what it meant to live in America. You could move around. You were afforded opportunities unavailable back home. You could refashion yourself a churchgoer, a pizza lover, an aficionado of classical music or Bob Dylan, a fan of the Dallas Cowboys because everyone else in the neighborhood seemed to be one.」
Young adulthood.title: Stay True

Middle adulthood.content: The Chinese community in the DC area is shrinking rapidly, making it increasingly harder for them(parent), especially as English is not their first language. My dad initially worked in a restaurant, but as it became more challenging, he switched to carpentry. He took on various jobs, from construction to fixing pipelines and even making furniture, showcasing his versatility.
Middle adulthood.title: Thesis Interviewee

Middle adulthood.content: 「My parents eventually decided that he would move back to Taiwan, too. A job as an executive awaited him. Never again would he have to dye his hair or touch his golf clubs. We bought two fax machines.」
Middle adulthood.title: Stay True

Early school years.content: I began playing basketball in third grade, around the same time as my older brother. Our mutual competitiveness made us better players. We often kept score, constantly pushing each other to improve. This sport was a significant part of my upbringing, as my family, including my brothers and cousins, all shared an interest in playing and watching basketball.
Early school years.title: Thesis Interviewee

Early school years.content: 「As Silicon Valley boomed in the early 1990s, so, too, did Taiwan’s semiconductor industry. Soon, my parents’ friends began moving back after decades away, maintaining homes in two countries so their children could finish high school and go to college in the States.」
Early school years.title: Stay True

Early school years.content: 「Among the items that survived my parents’ frugal early years are weathered paperback copies of the best sellers Future Shock and The Pentagon Papers.」
Early school years.concept: Pulitzer Prize Winner, cultural difference, memoir
Early school years.title: Stay True

Early school years.content: however when I returned to Japan I suddenly felt like an outsider meaning I no longer felt a sense of belonging to the Japanese school community or Jaclyn Society for instance we often did an in-class activity called on look where each student reads a sentence or a paragraph aloud although it may seem like a simple task I still remember my heart beating rapidly as I actually waited for a turn on Dooku was my biggest nightmare
Early school years.title: I Am Not Your Asian Stereotype | Canwen Xu | TEDxBoise

Toddlerhood.content: We predominantly speak Cantonese with our parents, occasionally using English for words we don't know in Cantonese. Sometimes, especially with my younger brother, sentences would be half in Cantonese and half in English, which could be challenging to understand. In my case, I estimate about 80 to 90% of my communication was in Cantonese and the rest in English. This bilingual communication was mostly with my parents, as I felt more comfortable speaking to them.
Toddlerhood.title: Thesis Interviewee

Toddlerhood.content: We often celebrated with birthday cakes and home-cooked food, especially dumplings. Those were memorable family moments, preparing and enjoying dumplings together for different occasions. For big celebrations, we sometimes drove a long way to have dim sum. We also went out for dinner to mark special events.
Toddlerhood.title: Thesis Interviewee

Toddlerhood.content: ““I’d walk by myself with my won to the local shop in my Korean neighborhood to get Korean cookies and treats. I was quite young in Korea.””
Toddlerhood.title: THE THIRD CULTURE KID (TCK) EXPERIENCE: ADULT-TCKS’ REFLECTIONS ON THEIR MULTICULTURAL CHILDHOOD ITS IMPACT ON STUDENT-TEACHER RELATIONSHIPS IN U.S. CLASSROOMS AND THEIR RECOMMEND
